description: From Middle English crucifix, from Old French crocefis (French crucifix), from Latin crucifixus.

entries.meaning: A wooden cross used for crucifixions, as by the Romans.
An ornamental or symbolic sculptural representation of Christ on a cross, often worn as a pendant or displayed in a Christian church.
examples: Plain crosses are preferred by Protestants, but crucifixes by Catholics.

entries.meaning: (gymnastics) The iron cross, a position on the rings where the gymnast holds the rings straight out on either side of the body.
